item.title: Ticket #44659 (Display custom fields) updated
item.dc:creator: iantresman
item.description:
It depends which part of the Wordpress Philosophy you read. I think the following extracts are relevant:

Great software should work with little configuration and setup Design for the Majority: Many end users of WordPress are non-technically minded.

I think most people don't use custom fields, because while they are trivial to enter the data, it is difficult to display it. I think this suggestion, with the ability to rewrite custom field data make it very useful, flexible and powerful.

-Also-

This is my first time posting here at the Wordpress Core, so please forgive me if I've made any error(s). I'm here to learn and am grateful to any input anyone can provide. Thanks ahead of time :)

item.title: Ticket #44667 (Trojan found em scan virus total) updated
item.dc:creator: swissspidy
item.description: Such false positives happened before, see #35318.

item.title: Ticket #44667 (Trojan found em scan virus total) closed
item.dc:creator: Clorith
item.description:
invalid:

Hi there, and welcome to WordPress trac!

WordPress is perfectly safe, so long as you download it from WordPress.org.

The report you linked us to shows a single false-positive from an off-brand virus provider, generally when using aggregated data, like the VirusTotal service, you will want more than a one-off report before it's considered a potential issue.

item.title: Ticket #44667 (Trojan found em scan virus total) created
item.dc:creator: jeimerson
item.description:
Hello, whenever I use any application, downloaded from the Internet, I use the site verustotal to examine, and with the latest version of WordPress I found a Trojan. Was this a site failure or does it really exist?

​https://www.virustotal.com/#/file/c983447a09159085b5a2839779e3925b66327330734cecb6ab09a9a40451c2a6/detection

Thank you very much.

item.title: Ticket #44659 (Display custom fields) updated
item.dc:creator: swissspidy
item.description:
Hey there

This sounds exactly like the Fields API project to me :-)

See ​https://make.wordpress.org/core/tag/fields-api/ and ​https://github.com/sc0ttkclark/wordpress-fields-api, as well as the #core-fields Slack channel.

item.title: Ticket #44661 (Page update issue) closed
item.dc:creator: swissspidy
item.description:
invalid:

Hi, and welcome to WordPress Trac!

Unfortunately this is not very specific and it's hard to tell whether it's just the browser being buggy or outdated, a browser addon, or something else.

I suggest you to ask for help at ​https://wordpress.org/support/ or in the #wordpress IRC channel on Freenode.

Make sure to include detailed information like WordPress version, browser version, OS, etc. It's also a good idea to run the ​Health Check plugin and to include screenshots or even a screencast.

item.title: Tickets #36177,​44663 batch updated
item.dc:creator: swissspidy
item.description:
duplicate:

Hey there

This has come up many times before, for example in #36177 and #30806.

Path disclosure is a server configuration problem. Never enable display_errors on a production site. See ​Security FAQ.

item.title: Ticket #44666 (Don't use hardcoded delete_post capability for custom post types) updated
item.dc:creator: swissspidy
item.description: get_delete_post_link() has the same wrong check apparently.

item.title: Ticket #44666 (Don't use hardcoded delete_post capability for custom post types) created
item.dc:creator: swissspidy
item.description:
The post list table as well as the publish meta box use the delete_post capability to check whether a user can delete or trash a post.

However, when registering a post type with a custom capability base, e.g. product, the actual capability will be delete_product.

The same goes for the capability check inside attachment_submit_meta_box() and perhaps other places too.

Related: #30991.

item.title: Ticket #44646 (Bundled Themes: Bump version number and update changelog in Twenty ...) reopened
item.dc:creator: celloexpressions
item.description:
Is it worth forcing every WordPress site that hasn't deleted this default theme to run an update that fixes one issue? While it's great to ship fixes to issues frequently, the update process is manual for nearly all users, and this theme is installed (but unused) on nearly all WordPress sites. The recent frequency of minor default theme releases is starting to be problematic for update fatigue.

Can we triage and incorporate some additional fixes before bundling a release, perhaps alongside 4.9.9? There are many other reported issues against Twenty Seventeen that would be worth fixing: https://core.trac.wordpress.org/query?status=accepted&status=assigned&status=new&status=reopened&status=reviewing&component=Bundled+Theme&summary=~Twenty+Seventeen&order=milestone

Historically, releasing bundled theme updates alongside core major releases 2-3 times a year has resulted in a reasonable balance between speed of development and frequency of updates. We're drifting pretty far in one direction with the current plan to ship a one-change update alongside 4.9.8, following two other smaller theme updates in the past few months. Reopening for visibility and discussion.

item.title: Ticket #44665 (Add a "Create New Menu" button to the menu widget) created
item.dc:creator: celloexpressions
item.description:
Menu widgets in the customizer have buttons to edit the selected menu, which cross-link to the menus customizer panel. Before a menu is selected, there should be a "Create New Menu" button that links to the new menu section and automatically assigns the menu to the corresponding widget.

This would be a big improvement in user flow, particularly for new users trying the menu widget for the first time, who may not understand the relationship between widget and menu objects. The UI should match the existing edit menu button.

item.title: Ticket #36612 (Add Ratings into the Add New Theme page) updated
item.dc:creator: celloexpressions
item.description:
Keywords changed

Thanks for adding an API field to support this. 36612.2.diff​ should be ready to go to use this (see screenshot above). Note that the link has to open in a new tab because the customizer can be opened in an iframe; the screen reader text warns users of this.

It looks like trunk may still be pulling from version 1.1 of the API; either way, this patch would work for 4.9.X, then we can adjust for trunk if it switches to 1.2. We can just exclude the changes to wp-includes/class-wp-customize-manager.php.

item.title: 36612.2.png attached to Ticket #36612
item.dc:creator: celloexpressions
item.description: With 36612.2.diff

item.title: 36612.2.diff attached to Ticket #36612
item.dc:creator: celloexpressions
item.description: Add a link to view theme ratings, loading the link from the .org API.

item.title: Ticket #44664 (Twenty Fourteen: Video play icon alignment) created
item.dc:creator: celloexpressions
item.description:
Twenty Fourteen provides custom styling for the MediaElement.js players. It appears that the updates to MediaElement.js in a recent release caused the play icon (which is a Genericons font icon) in embedded video players to become substantially misaligned. This could be seen in the editor or in a video widget with a locally-uploaded video.

This seems to be fixable by adding position: relative to .hentry .mejs-overlay-button, .widget .mejs-overlay-button { in the Twenty Fourteen stylesheet. This allows the icon to be absolutely positioned relative to the button container, as this worked previously.

If someone has time to verify this issue, document screenshots, and turn this into a patch, this should be a relatively straightforward fix.

item.title: Ticket #44663 (Disallow direct access to wp-includes php files) created
item.dc:creator: lucasbustamante
item.description:
Running WP Scan on my website, I saw a full path disclosure vulnerability under wp-includes/rss-functions.php

Error code: 

<?php
Call to undefined function _deprecated_file() in /home/mydomain/public_html/wp-includes/rss-functions.php on line 8

This is it's source code: 

<?php
<?php
/**
 * Deprecated. Use rss.php instead.
 *
 * @package WordPress
 */
_deprecated_file( basename(__FILE__), '2.1.0', WPINC . '/rss.php' );
require_once( ABSPATH . WPINC . '/rss.php' );

A lot of files under wp-includes look similar to this one.

I wonder if it would make sense to prevent direct access to these files, since it uses _deprecated_file() function, which is loaded with WordPress. 

<?php
if ( ! defined( 'ABSPATH' ) ) exit;

I have turned off display_errors on my website, but still, makes sense to me. Other people are having this issue, and many others don't even know what WP Scan is and are vulnerable without even knowing.

​https://wordpress.stackexchange.com/questions/203123/full-path-disclosure-on-rss-functions-php
